title: Hamilton Anxiety Scale
description: Rates level of anxiety based on clinical questions. Assesses the severity of anxiety symptoms across 14 domains in patients already diagnosed with anxiety disorders.

parameters.name: anxious_mood
parameters.description: Worries, anticipation of worst, fearful anticipation, irritability

parameters.name: tension
parameters.description: Feelings of tension, fatigability, startle response, easily moved to tears, trembling, restlessness, inability to relax

parameters.name: fears
parameters.description: Of dark, strangers, being left alone, animals, traffic, crowds

parameters.name: insomnia
parameters.description: Difficulty falling asleep, broken sleep, unsatisfying sleep, fatigue on waking, dreams, nightmares, night terrors

parameters.name: depressed_mood
parameters.description: Loss of interest, lack of pleasure in hobbies, depression, early waking, diurnal swing

parameters.name: somatic_muscular
parameters.description: Pains, aches, twitching, stiffness, myoclonic jerks, teeth grinding, unsteady voice, increased muscle tone

parameters.name: somatic_sensory
parameters.description: Tinnitus, blurring vision, hot/cold flushes, feelings of weakness, pricking sensation

parameters.name: cardiovascular
parameters.description: Tachycardia, palpitations, chest pain, throbbing vessels, fainting feelings, missing heartbeat

parameters.name: respiratory
parameters.description: Pressure/constriction in chest, choking feelings, sighing, dyspnea

parameters.name: gastrointestinal
parameters.description: Swallowing difficulty, wind, abdominal pain, burning sensations, fullness, nausea, vomiting, bowel changes, weight loss, constipation

parameters.name: genitourinary
parameters.description: Urinary frequency/urgency, menstrual changes, sexual dysfunction

parameters.name: autonomic_symptoms
parameters.description: Dry mouth, flushing, pallor, sweating, giddiness, tension headache, hair raising

parameters.name: behavior_at_interview
parameters.description: Fidgeting, restlessness, hand tremor, furrowed brow, strained face, sighing, rapid respiration, facial pallor

ranges.interpretation: Patient reports no significant anxiety symptoms or experiences minimal anxiety that does not interfere with daily functioning. No specific intervention typically required.
Patient experiences mild anxiety symptoms that may cause some distress but generally do not significantly impair functioning. Consider monitoring and supportive interventions.
Patient experiences moderate anxiety symptoms that interfere with daily activities and quality of life. Consider psychotherapy and/or pharmacological intervention.
Patient experiences severe anxiety symptoms that significantly impair functioning and quality of life. Strongly consider intensive treatment including medication and psychotherapy.

references: Hamilton M. The assessment of anxiety states by rating. Br J Med Psychol. 1959;32(1):50-5. doi: 10.1111/j.2044-8341.1959.tb00467.x.

Matza LS, Morlock R, Sexton C, Malley K, Feltner D. Identifying HAM-A cutoffs for mild, moderate, and severe generalized anxiety disorder. Int J Methods Psychiatr Res. 2010 Dec;19(4):223-32. doi: 10.1002/mpr.323.

Shear MK, Vander Bilt J, Rucci P, Endicott J, Lydiard B, Otto MW, et al. Reliability and validity of a structured interview guide for the Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale (SIGH-A). Depress Anxiety. 2001;13(4):166-78. doi: 10.1002/da.1033.
formula: HAM-A Score = Sum of all 14 item scores (each rated 0-4)
notes: Each item is rated on a 5-point scale: 0=Not Present, 1=Mild, 2=Moderate, 3=Severe, 4=Very Severe
Originally designed for patients already diagnosed with anxiety disorders
Can be used for initial assessment or to monitor treatment response
Higher scores indicate more severe anxiety symptoms
